item.title: The first thing we need to know is that there are several ways physical systems can compute convolutions. Linear-time-invariant systems implement causal temporal convolutions. Fourier optics implement spatial convolutions physically. 2/ https://t.co/4Q7QGu0DFq
item.description: The first thing we need to know is that there are several ways physical systems can compute convolutions. Linear-time-invariant systems implement causal temporal convolutions. Fourier optics implement spatial convolutions physically. 2/ https://t.co/4Q7QGu0DFq
item.content:encoded: The first thing we need to know is that there are several ways physical systems can compute convolutions. Linear-time-invariant systems implement causal temporal convolutions. Fourier optics implement spatial convolutions physically. 2/ https://t.co/4Q7QGu0DFq

item.title: So if we have convolutions and nothing else... we can already get linear (convolution-based) classifiers. They use this to demo an MNIST-based classifier leveraging the transfer function of a speaker, oscillating plate and microphone. 3/ https://t.co/NTIjGuTYpy
item.description: So if we have convolutions and nothing else... we can already get linear (convolution-based) classifiers. They use this to demo an MNIST-based classifier leveraging the transfer function of a speaker, oscillating plate and microphone. 3/ https://t.co/NTIjGuTYpy
item.content:encoded: So if we have convolutions and nothing else... we can already get linear (convolution-based) classifiers. They use this to demo an MNIST-based classifier leveraging the transfer function of a speaker, oscillating plate and microphone. 3/ https://t.co/NTIjGuTYpy

item.title: Unroll 2-d digits as waveforms, play them back through the speaker, the plate distorts the sound, which is recorded by the microphone. They cheat a bit by having trainable in-silico element-wise scalings. But you could imagine having physical adjustable elements instead. 4/ https://t.co/xfqudYGfBK
item.description: Unroll 2-d digits as waveforms, play them back through the speaker, the plate distorts the sound, which is recorded by the microphone. They cheat a bit by having trainable in-silico element-wise scalings. But you could imagine having physical adjustable elements instead. 4/ https://t.co/xfqudYGfBK
item.content:encoded: Unroll 2-d digits as waveforms, play them back through the speaker, the plate distorts the sound, which is recorded by the microphone. They cheat a bit by having trainable in-silico element-wise scalings. But you could imagine having physical adjustable elements instead. 4/ https://t.co/xfqudYGfBK

item.title: That system is linear, so it's not very useful (gets 87% MNIST accuracy). It's also very easy to train because we can fully characterize the LTI system using classical systems identification methods and calculate the optimal weights that way. 5/
item.description: That system is linear, so it's not very useful (gets 87% MNIST accuracy). It's also very easy to train because we can fully characterize the LTI system using classical systems identification methods and calculate the optimal weights that way. 5/
item.content:encoded: That system is linear, so it's not very useful (gets 87% MNIST accuracy). It's also very easy to train because we can fully characterize the LTI system using classical systems identification methods and calculate the optimal weights that way. 5/

item.title: They move on to harder systems, including nonlinear optics systems and nonlinear oscillators. These systems are nonlinear, so can compute useful things, and are also harder to characterize and train. They still use convolutions as their core operation 6/ https://t.co/UFiXnTdK5V
item.description: They move on to harder systems, including nonlinear optics systems and nonlinear oscillators. These systems are nonlinear, so can compute useful things, and are also harder to characterize and train. They still use convolutions as their core operation 6/ https://t.co/UFiXnTdK5V
item.content:encoded: They move on to harder systems, including nonlinear optics systems and nonlinear oscillators. These systems are nonlinear, so can compute useful things, and are also harder to characterize and train. They still use convolutions as their core operation 6/ https://t.co/UFiXnTdK5V

item.title: How to train then? They do the forward pass with the physical systems. But you can't backdrop through physical systems. Instead, they backprop through an in silico model of the system built through nonlinear systems identification. 7/ https://t.co/8VayXEwLEk
item.description: How to train then? They do the forward pass with the physical systems. But you can't backdrop through physical systems. Instead, they backprop through an in silico model of the system built through nonlinear systems identification. 7/ https://t.co/8VayXEwLEk
item.content:encoded: How to train then? They do the forward pass with the physical systems. But you can't backdrop through physical systems. Instead, they backprop through an in silico model of the system built through nonlinear systems identification. 7/ https://t.co/8VayXEwLEk

item.title: The fact that they use a forward pass through the physical system means their error vector is "correct", even if their digital model is not quite accurate. But of course the digital model is necessary for backprop, otherwise they'd need finite differences, which doesn't scale. 8/
item.description: The fact that they use a forward pass through the physical system means their error vector is "correct", even if their digital model is not quite accurate. But of course the digital model is necessary for backprop, otherwise they'd need finite differences, which doesn't scale. 8/
item.content:encoded: The fact that they use a forward pass through the physical system means their error vector is "correct", even if their digital model is not quite accurate. But of course the digital model is necessary for backprop, otherwise they'd need finite differences, which doesn't scale. 8/

item.title: At 97% accuracy on MNIST, this is not about to bankrupt NVIDIA. But there are some interesting ideas in there about controlling non-differentiable physical systems (like the brain!) through hybrid physical/ANN modelling and alternatives to backprop. 9/9 https://t.co/sD8uKJKrr0
